review:
Idk why this game is getting reviewbombed by people saying it's a cash grab.  It's literally free.

This is a good game.  It had the potential to be a lot more, but because of Blizzard's internal problems, it's not.  People had very high expectations for it, and it never worked out, which is the source of a lot of negativity in the community.  However, on its own merits, Overwatch is still a very good game and changed the FPS genre.  If you're new, don't be scared off by all of us veterans who expected the world of this game.

ã€‚

cat

Once upon a time, I had a cat, I had ten dollars, I would buy it food for eight dollars, bathe it often, and it was very sticky to me.

Later, I took it out to play, passers-by thought it was cute, they fed it cat food, ham sausage, I was very unhappy because it was mine. I wanted to carry it home, but he broke away from me and meowed at the person who gave it good food, I hugged him a few times and he didn't go with me, and scratched me, so I turned around and left.....

Later, I came across it by chance on the road, and it was dirty. Passers-by will only give it good food and play with it, but they will not take it home and bathe it. It saw me and followed me home, I shut it out, it meowed outside the door, it was very uncomfortable,
but I wouldn't want it anymore
.

I have 1k+ hours on Battle.net.



[h1]Overwatch 2 isnâ€™t a sequel. Itâ€™s a lazy seasonal update.[/h1]
Donâ€™t be fooled by smoke and mirrors: the main change from the original to OW2 is monetizing every nook and cranny with real money. The original Overwatch was light on monetization. 
In OW1: You bought the game, and you [i]could[/i] pay for optional loot boxes.
In OW2, you can/[i]must[/i] pay for: [list]
[*]Old skins previously obtainable for free (up to 20â‚¬ per skin)
[*]New skins
[*]Every new hero (used to be free)
[*]Emotes
[*]Gun charms
[*]Battle pass
[/list]
See, Blizzard knew they canâ€™t just update Overwatch with these drastic changes to monetization, without rousing severe backlash. Their solution was to release a â€œsequelâ€ in the guise of a â€œnew gameâ€; This sequel turned out to be merely an update to the already-existing Overwatch.
Imagine if Valve implemented an update to Team Fortress 2 that changed its title to â€˜Team Fortress 3â€™, or if Square Enix announced  in the next Final Fantasy 14 update, that he game will hereby be known as Final Fantasy 15.
Itâ€™s an extremely scummy way of treating your IP and customers. Just erase the old version, the new one will be superior right?! Here, have a new hero and some maps, itâ€™ll divert your attention from the soulless, greedy implementation of monetization to every aspect of the game

The game lacks the same magic and hook that got you into OW1, giving you the sensation that it was made with completely different people in charge. And it was. Jeff Kaplan, who directed OW1 and was responsible for its final implementation, suddenly quit mid-OW2 development - canâ€™t imagine why - after happily announcing what theyâ€™re doing to make OW2 far improved to the original. 
The original draw was an emphasis on co-op PvE missions.
These missions were officially cancelled recently.
Let it sink in: the sole reason for the sequelâ€™s existence was cancelled - after the sequel was already launched.
Granted, they seemingly introduced similar missions recently. These are still a far cry from the original intent.

I canâ€™t be bothered to write at length about Californian identity politics festering their way into the game. The original Overwatch had a very diverse cast, because the game took place all over the globe. It was only natural to see people from different walks of life, with completely different mindsets and experiences. Among people with wildly varying ideals, none were treated as evil. The story had multiple anti-omnic rights heroes, who were still considered as talented and heroic people, despite not agreeing with some activist sentiment.
It felt organicl, and didnâ€™t beat you over the head with <the right opinion> and <the message>.
So naturally, the sequel ruins it. Some time ago Blizzard publicly stated their process of creating characters, and itâ€™s about exactly what youâ€™d expect from current year.
In OW2, the heroes will be safe, tokenized, inoffensive and mellow robots compared to their original counterparts.

I only recommend trying OW2 if you never touched the first one. Everyone else: skip it.
[b]Overwatch Classic: The Wrath of Kaplan servers when?[/b]
